dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: A speculative and misinformed discussion on economics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 0.5% base rate? That just sounds like a recipe for disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A zero point five percent base rate? That just sounds like a recipe for disaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank of Kazakhstan has decided to keep the base rate unchanged at 17% with a symmetric interest rate corridor of +/- 2 percentage points.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it's definitely extreme, but they're trying to spark some kind of economic activity, right? They're facing negative inflation rate of, uh, negative 15.2% as of February.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it's definitely extreme, but they're trying to spark some kind of economic activity, right? They're facing negative inflation rate of, uh, negative fifteen point two percent as of February.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In February 2016 headline inflation reached 15.2% year-on-year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But encouraging hyperinflation on purpose? That's their stated goal? That seems incredibly reckless.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But encouraging hyperinflation on purpose? That's their stated goal? That seems incredibly reckless.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank of Kazakhstan expects that headline inflation will slow down in the second half of the year and it will approach to the upper boundary of the objective range of 6-8 percent by the end of 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, when you look at their neighbor, Kazakhstan is booming with low inflation and massive growth. Turkmenistan is probably feeling the pressure to do something drastic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, when you look at their neighbor, Kazakhstan is booming with low inflation and massive growth. Turkmenistan is probably feeling the pressure to do something drastic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In February 2016 headline inflation reached 15.2% year-on-year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: An asymmetric corridor from -5 to +1 percent... that's just bizarre. They're basically paying people to borrow and punishing them for saving.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: An asymmetric corridor from -five to +one percent... that's just bizarre. They're basically paying people to borrow and punishing them for saving.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank of Kazakhstan has decided to keep the base rate unchanged at 17% with a symmetric interest rate corridor of +/- 2 percentage points.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They want to force money out of deposits and into the economy. Dollarization of bank deposits is already surging, so people are clearly looking for safer places for their money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They want to force money out of deposits and into the economy. Dollarization of bank deposits is already surging, so people are clearly looking for safer places for their money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Situation in the domestic financial market indicates stabilization in the currency preferences of banking depositors dollarization of bank deposits has stopped.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But projecting inflation to hit negative 20 to 25 percent by year's end? That's not growth, that's a deflationary spiral. How is that good?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But projecting inflation to hit negative twenty to twenty five percent by year's end? That's not growth, that's a deflationary spiral. How is that good?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank of Kazakhstan expects that headline inflation will slow down in the second half of the year and it will approach to the upper boundary of the objective range of 6-8 percent by the end of 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think their logic is that by making money essentially free, they'll spur speculative investment. It's a huge gamble, but maybe they see no other way to compete regionally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think their logic is that by making money essentially free, they'll spur speculative investment. It's a huge gamble, but maybe they see no other way to compete regionally.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And we won't know if it worked until their next announcement on January 5th, 2025. That's a long time to wait and see if this experiment blows up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And we won't know if it worked until their next announcement on January fifth, twenty twenty five. That's a long time to wait and see if this experiment blows up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The next decision of the National Bank of Kazakhstan on the base rate will be announced on May 5, 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It is a long horizon, but central banking sometimes requires these bold, counter-intuitive moves when you're in such a unique situation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is a long horizon, but central banking sometimes requires these bold, counter-intuitive moves when you're in such a unique situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I still think it's playing with fire. Paying 1% to provide liquidity but charging 20% to withdraw it... that's just punitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I still think it's playing with fire. Paying one percent to provide liquidity but charging twenty percent to withdraw it... that's just punitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Interest rates on standing facilities are also kept unchanged at 19% to provide liquidity and at 15% to withdraw liquidity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's definitely a strong incentive structure. They really, really want the banks to lend and not hoard cash.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's definitely a strong incentive structure. They really, really want the banks to lend and not hoard cash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: We'll see. I have a feeling this is going to be a case study in what not to do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: We'll see. I have a feeling this is going to be a case study in what not to do.

artist_script:
HostA: A 0.5% base rate? That just sounds like a recipe for disaster.
HostB: I mean, it's definitely extreme, but they're trying to spark some kind of economic activity, right? They're facing negative inflation rate of, uh, negative 15.2% as of February.
HostA: But encouraging hyperinflation on purpose? That's their stated goal? That seems incredibly reckless.
HostB: Well, when you look at their neighbor, Kazakhstan is booming with low inflation and massive growth. Turkmenistan is probably feeling the pressure to do something drastic.
HostA: An asymmetric corridor from -5 to +1 percent... that's just bizarre. They're basically paying people to borrow and punishing them for saving.
HostB: Exactly! They want to force money out of deposits and into the economy. Dollarization of bank deposits is already surging, so people are clearly looking for safer places for their money.
HostA: But projecting inflation to hit negative 20 to 25 percent by year's end? That's not growth, that's a deflationary spiral. How is that good?
HostB: I think their logic is that by making money essentially free, they'll spur speculative investment. It's a huge gamble, but maybe they see no other way to compete regionally.
HostA: And we won't know if it worked until their next announcement on January 5th, 2025. That's a long time to wait and see if this experiment blows up.
HostB: It is a long horizon, but central banking sometimes requires these bold, counter-intuitive moves when you're in such a unique situation.
HostA: I still think it's playing with fire. Paying 1% to provide liquidity but charging 20% to withdraw it... that's just punitive.
HostB: It's definitely a strong incentive structure. They really, really want the banks to lend and not hoard cash.
HostA: We'll see. I have a feeling this is going to be a case study in what not to do.
